BC-FAMILY-DOG-TRAIN-530(2TAKES)-NYTR 
AT OBEDIENCE CAMP, DOGS AND KIDS LEARN A FEW NEW TRICKS 

  
 (ATTN: Calif.)  (js) 
 By SUZANNE BOYNTON   The Press Democrat (Santa Rosa,
Calif.)   c.1998 N.Y. Times News Service   

   SANTA ROSA, Calif. _ Louie, a formerly timid miniature poodle,
stood on his hind feet and walked backward while Benjamin Rait, 13,
held a cookie over his head, garnering the ``best trick'' vote from
fellow campers.

   Winston, a 90-pound black Labrador retriever, escaped from the
after-lunch nap area without 60-pound James Ryall, 9, but was
captured by an instructor. On the second try, he sat until James
invited him out the door.

   Sterling Weir, 9, lay across the body of his ``dead''
mixed-breed, Kosar, and wailed. Then the pair jumped up and took
their bows.

   Amber, a small golden retriever, really didn't want to go
through the obstacle course tunnel, but was coaxed through by Julia
Ponder, 11, and Nancy Pierson, an instructor, who stood at each end
of the tube and used an extra treat. ``When in doubt, throw an
extra cookie,'' quipped Nancy.

   It was a typical day at Camp Best Friends, a one-week day camp
for kids ages 9 to 13 and their dogs, conducted for the first time
in mid-August at Best Friends Dog Training and day care facility in
southwest Santa Rosa. Best Friends is owned by Julee Fullenwider,
who led the camp with instructors Pierson and Pat Engle.

   While the camp's first day had been fairly chaotic, said
Fullenwider, by the last day, the kids had fairly good control of
their dogs. The camp's goal was to give the youngsters a format for
thinking about and relating to their pets. Even parents who know
how to train dogs themselves don't always teach their children how,
said Fullenwider. ``They'll say `don't do that,' but don't tell
them what to do.''

   Take Amber and Julia, for instance. ``Amber used to not listen
to me,'' said Julia. ``Now she listens to me a lot better.'' It
wasn't that Amber didn't know what she was supposed to do _ she had
previously attended obedience classes with Julia's mother, Janet
Ponder. The camp taught Julia how to take command.

   Local trainers agree it's important to involve the whole family
in the selection, training and care of a family pet. Children are
often expected to care for an animal, but are not taught to train.
In return, the dog ignores the child.

   Jan Warz, who teaches dog training classes for the Humane
Society of Sonoma County animal shelter and Sebastopol Community
Center, says the point of dog training classes is training people.
She takes children as young as 7 in her classes.

   The most common problem children have in relating to the family
dog involves motivation, not a lack of training skills or
responsibility, said Warz. ``It occurs when the child is not part
of the decision to select the animal. A lot of parents have a
picture of the kind of dog they want to live with. They get the
dog, supposedly for the child, and expect the child to buy into
it.''

   The notion that children are irresponsible when it comes to
caring for and training the family dog, said Warz, is ``just not
true. There are some physical restrictions - it's terrible to have
a tiny 7-year-old come in with a huge (untrained) malamute ...
That's not fair for the dog, but it's really not fair for the
child. We try to set things up for success.''

   Warz said where dog training is concerned, children have the
advantage that ``they don't have all the baggage we adults do. If I
say to the class that we're going to work these dogs and then
reward them with praise, the child knows how he feels about that.
He will get on the floor and roll with 'em. A child is very attuned
to the relationship developing between them and their dog.''

   Nancy Beliveau, daughter of a professional field-dog trainer,
was only 9 when she started training her father's clients. She
finds that when it comes to dog handling, ``children can do
basically the same as an adult.''

   The only catch, said Beliveau, is that the child must have the
dog's respect and trust in order to make it behave properly. ``Kids
are not as assertive as they should be with the dog. He should be a
little bit worried that you're the alpha dog and could correct
him,'' Beliveau said.

   Austin Davis, 8, achieved just that at camp. Major, a German
shepherd mix adopted in June from the Rohnert Park shelter,
wouldn't listen to him, though Major obeyed Austin's parents. But
after the first day at camp, Austin said, ``He was like, oh-oh,
here comes Julee _ oh-oh, here comes Austin.''

   Fullenwider believes this first-day phenomenon was simply due to
the fact that for the first time, each child-dog team had spent a
lot of time concentrating on each other.

   ``For five hours, we were consistently expecting the kids to be
in control of the dogs. They were getting rewarded for controlling
the dogs. Three of us (instructors) were watching them, reminding
them. Our patience didn't wear down _ we knew they were going
home.''

   Dogs that were dedicated to pulling on their leashes got prong
collars, which press the blunt ends of several stiff wires into the
neck when the dog pulls. The training itself, though, was not
intimidating for the dogs. The sternest discipline was a spritz of
diluted vinegar water in the face, administered by instructors
only, for the high crime of barking. (Don't do this at home without
proper directions, Fullenwider warns; unless applied correctly, it
won't work.)

   By the end of the camp, the children had learned to make their
dogs heel, sit, lie down and stay (most of the time) and do tricks,
mostly of the dog's choice. These behaviors were emphasized in
games like tic-tac-toe, wherein the child was required to make the
dog sit or lie down and stay in order to hold the square on a board
painted on the floor of Fullenwider's training center.

   Other games emphasized just-for-fun teamwork between child and
dog. In ``bobbing for hot dogs,'' the children directed their
canines' attention to a bucket of water in which hot dog pieces
were floating. Most dogs took little directing to find and gobble
up the treats.

   In the T-shirt relay, the child dressed the dog in a T-shirt,
walked a course with the dog at heel, then removed the shirt for
the next team member. There was an obstacle course for agility.

   Campers heard speakers on veterinary care, and learned to groom
their dogs and brush their teeth. There were videos, a daily craft
period after lunch where campers made things like doggie treats and
thank-you cards for the speakers, and lessons in Tellington Touch,
an internationally practiced form of acupressure-type massage.

   Of the latter, Fullenwider said, ``The founder feels that touch
at certain places on a dog's body can help with certain ailments.
But where I'm coming from is, I think it's a great calming exercise
for the dog, and gives kids a structure rather than pulling on
their ears.''

   ``We want them to learn different ways of playing with the dog
and controlling the dog.''

   Parents who came to watch the video the children had made on the
last day of camp said the camp had succeeded in showing their
children how to handle their dogs.

   ``Julia had a close relationship with Amber before, but this has
made it even closer. I think maybe Amber has taught Julia a few
tricks,'' said Julia's dad, Steve Ponder.

   Alfie, a mixed breed, was also recently adopted from a shelter.
As far as training, ``He started from zero. Camp has been a really
good experience for my daughter,'' said Bev Zeigler, watching
Josie, 12, catapult a tennis ball for Alfie to catch. ``During
camp, we tried to let her take care of him. We'll have to see now
that camp's over whether she'll keep it up.''

   Zeigler added, ``She feels more in control. The dog's more under
control. It's definitely a good thing.''

   (Suzanne Boynton writes for The Press Democrat in Santa Rosa,
Calif.)
